Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: The Integrated Future of Additive Manufacturing, Design, Production and Qualification; Alexandria, Virginia; July 23-24, 2018

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop brings together leading experts in the field of 3D printing to discuss and identify the current challenges to be addressed and the revolutionary future opportunities enabled by this broad and rapidly expanding field. Interdisciplinary groups formed across material and processing disciplines, and composed of a vibrant mix of academic, government, and industry participants, will provide a creative yet realistic view of the transformative potential of additive manufacturing. The cross-disciplinary discussions will hone a broad range of opinions and visions towards a common agreement on the major issues and avenues towards innovative solutions. Further, if these solutions are successful, what new commercial opportunities, technical areas of study, and other societal benefits will result. The workshop will be held at NSF Headquarters, Alexandria, Virginia, July 23-24, 2018.

The future of Additive Manufacturing (AM) relies on the seamless integration of design, production, and qualification of functional parts. These three high level topics will be addressed across five working groups: (1) functional materials and structures, (2) 3D printing processes, (3) embedded instrumentation and methods for in-situ monitoring and real-time process control, (4) process informed multi-objective design tools, and (5) logistics and mass customization. The frontiers of each subtopic, their challenges, and potential solutions to them will be discussed across working groups. The results of these discussions will help frame future areas of research and opportunities if these challenges are solved.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
3D printing, a sub-category of additive manufacturing, has created a new design paradigm across academic, industry, and governmental fields. In combination with computer simulation, physical prototyping has sped up and reduced the cost of bringing new products to manufacture by orders of magnitude. Concurrent with the widespread adoption of 3D printing for prototyping, academic and government labs have produced numerous examples of fantastic abilities derived from exquisite control over spatial and material design. In spite of these dramatic demonstrations and paradigm shifting potential, to this date there have been few examples of directly 3D printing functional components for end-use applications. In the few instances where 3D printing is used for direct production, an important technological milestone has been achieved (e.g., CLIP for the mass customization of ADIDAS shoes). It is the goal of this report to identify the potential for 3D printing and what technological milestones must be achieved to realize this potential.  While there are many technological challenges and desirable goals that were discussed, the key scientific challenges to AM’s future capabilities were identified as: 1. A chemo-physical description of printability: An understanding of what chemical and physical properties define ‘printability’ is lacking. While certain physical phenomena are known, no all-encompassing multi-physical framework exists to capture even a single AM technique. A description of printability could provide a directional roadmap to promising new materials development.2. Tunable material-structure properties: Material selection charts contain vast untapped spaces in which a combination of multi-phase composite materials and micro-/meso-structured geometries can offer orders-of-magnitude improvements in performance, and which cannot be achieved except by AM processes. Fundamental knowledge is lacking in both the prediction of how to translate selected multi-phase materials with AM structured geometries into these open performance spaces and how AM techniques must be adapted to these multi-phase material systems.3. Material interfaces: The understanding of and prediction of interface quality within AM parts, and the connection of this quality to part performance is lacking. AM parts contain substantial internal interfacial area that is orders of magnitude greater than in traditionally manufactured parts. The knowledge gap of interfacial effects exists both for homogeneous and heterogeneous material. Whereas homogeneous materials have chemical compatibility across the interface, heterogeneous materials add adhesive incompatibility as an additional factor to study.4. High level, abstracted design tools: Design thinking and approaches do not address the parametric openness required for function-driven design. End users require function, and are increasingly removing requirements for specific materials or forms (i.e., geometries). Moreover, redefinition of constraints often requires extreme redesigns that cannot be handled within existing design paradigms.5. Sensing for Single-Part Certification: Sensors and their use within AM and within parts produced by AM are almost completely unstudied despite their transformational application to modern manufacturing. Closed-loop AM is restricted by a lack of suitable control systems and decision-making approaches suitable for the massive quantities of data generated during AM processing. The connection of these data to part qualification requirements is unknown. Sensors can also be integrated during AM within products, but how this could be used for part qualification as well as in-field life analysis remains unaddressed. 

Solutions to these key scientific challenges to AM’s future capabilities were identified as: 1. Model generation and printability testing to predict new materials: Multi-physical models which can use existing material databases to predict and select optimal materials for printing should be developed. New or modified tests to determine new materials’ suitability for printing could be paired with high throughput testing to feed Materials Genome-like databases that form the foundation of optimization and design tools.2. Tunable Material Properties: Material selection charts (i.e., Ashby charts) clearly show open space in modulus-density, yield stress-density, thermal expansion-thermal conductivity, or almost any other combination of material properties of interest to a designer. The translation of of a multi-decade knowledge effort in composite materials and their structures into the AM processing space, which often entails extreme heating/cooling rates, thermal gradients, deformation rates, or other conditions, could enable access to these previously unrealized performance spaces.3. Material interfaces: Efforts to predict the interface quality will require translational research from the physical chemistry, adhesive, and processing communities to link atomic/molecular forces, mesoscale phenomena, and printed geometries to predict part performance.4. High level, abstracted design tools: New digital conceptions linking AM design decisions with data from materials and processing databases are required to handle this open-ended design challenge.5. Sensing for Single-Part Certification: The ability to observe, control, and make decisions on the quality of these instantly produced replacement parts requires a multi-disciplinary combination of controls systems, big data management, sensing, physics and modeling, and manufacturing engineering disciplines.

A longer-term broader impact of the workshop will be its support of transformative research that will fuel U.S. economic growth.

Modified by: Robert Shepherd

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: 3D printing, a sub-category of additive manufacturing, has created a new design paradigm across academic, industry, and governmental fields. In combination with computer simulation, physical prototyping has sped up and reduced the cost of bringing new products to manufacture by orders of magnitude. Concurrent with the widespread adoption of 3D printing for prototyping, academic and government labs have produced numerous examples of fantastic abilities derived from exquisite control over spatial and material design. In spite of these dramatic demonstrations and paradigm shifting potential, to this date there have been few examples of directly 3D printing functional components for end-use applications. In the few instances where 3D printing is used for direct production, an important technological milestone has been achieved (e.g., CLIP for the mass customization of ADIDAS shoes). It is the goal of this report to identify the potential for 3D printing and what technological milestones must be achieved to realize this potential. While there are many technological challenges and desirable goals that were discussed, the key scientific challenges to AM?s future capabilities were identified as: 1. A chemo-physical description of printability: An understanding of what chemical and physical properties define ?printability? is lacking. While certain physical phenomena are known, no all-encompassing multi-physical framework exists to capture even a single AM technique. A description of printability could provide a directional roadmap to promising new materials development.2. Tunable material-structure properties: Material selection charts contain vast untapped spaces in which a combination of multi-phase composite materials and micro-/meso-structured geometries can offer orders-of-magnitude improvements in performance, and which cannot be achieved except by AM processes. Fundamental knowledge is lacking in both the prediction of how to translate selected multi-phase materials with AM structured geometries into these open performance spaces and how AM techniques must be adapted to these multi-phase material systems.3. Material interfaces: The understanding of and prediction of interface quality within AM parts, and the connection of this quality to part performance is lacking. AM parts contain substantial internal interfacial area that is orders of magnitude greater than in traditionally manufactured parts. The knowledge gap of interfacial effects exists both for homogeneous and heterogeneous material. Whereas homogeneous materials have chemical compatibility across the interface, heterogeneous materials add adhesive incompatibility as an additional factor to study.4. High level, abstracted design tools: Design thinking and approaches do not address the parametric openness required for function-driven design. End users require function, and are increasingly removing requirements for specific materials or forms (i.e., geometries). Moreover, redefinition of constraints often requires extreme redesigns that cannot be handled within existing design paradigms.5. Sensing for Single-Part Certification: Sensors and their use within AM and within parts produced by AM are almost completely unstudied despite their transformational application to modern manufacturing. Closed-loop AM is restricted by a lack of suitable control systems and decision-making approaches suitable for the massive quantities of data generated during AM processing. The connection of these data to part qualification requirements is unknown. Sensors can also be integrated during AM within products, but how this could be used for part qualification as well as in-field life analysis remains unaddressed. Solutions to these key scientific challenges to AM?s future capabilities were identified as: 1. Model generation and printability testing to predict new materials: Multi-physical models which can use existing material databases to predict and select optimal materials for printing should be developed. New or modified tests to determine new materials? suitability for printing could be paired with high throughput testing to feed Materials Genome-like databases that form the foundation of optimization and design tools.2. Tunable Material Properties: Material selection charts (i.e., Ashby charts) clearly show open space in modulus-density, yield stress-density, thermal expansion-thermal conductivity, or almost any other combination of material properties of interest to a designer. The translation of of a multi-decade knowledge effort in composite materials and their structures into the AM processing space, which often entails extreme heating/cooling rates, thermal gradients, deformation rates, or other conditions, could enable access to these previously unrealized performance spaces.3. Material interfaces: Efforts to predict the interface quality will require translational research from the physical chemistry, adhesive, and processing communities to link atomic/molecular forces, mesoscale phenomena, and printed geometries to predict part performance.4. High level, abstracted design tools: New digital conceptions linking AM design decisions with data from materials and processing databases are required to handle this open-ended design challenge.5. Sensing for Single-Part Certification: The ability to observe, control, and make decisions on the quality of these instantly produced replacement parts requires a multi-disciplinary combination of controls systems, big data management, sensing, physics and modeling, and manufacturing engineering disciplines. A longer-term broader impact of the workshop will be its support of transformative research that will fuel U.S. economic growth. Last Modified: 09/13/2019 Submitted by: Robert Shepherd
